image.altText: Side profile of James Hayward.

items.synopsis: A former WA MP is sentenced to almost three years in jail for sexually abusing a young girl, the same year he sought election to the state's upper house.

title.children: 'Catastrophic' fall: Former WA MP James Hayward jailed for child sex offences

image.altText: A group of Middle Eastern people stand in a car park next to a gated tin shed on sunny day

items.synopsis: What do you want to know about the Israel-Gaza war? Our global affairs correspondent John Lyons has been reporting from Israel along with the ABC team and is ready to answer your questions from 7:30pm AEDT. Follow live.

title.children: Ask our correspondent John Lyons your questions on the Israel-Gaza war

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Al Jazeera is reporting that Israel is not permitting the opening of the Egyptian border crossing. Can the ABC confirm this? Is DFAT still advising Australians to move south? - D. I’m not sure what DFAT’s latest advice is — it would be on their website — but I do know that the south is likely to be less dangerous than the centre (Gaza City) and the north. I say “less dangerous” because no-where in Gaza is safe. It’s so small and there’s no-where to get away from the war. In geographic size it’s about half the size of Canberra with 2.3 million people. To put that into an Australian perspective, imagine putting the population of Brisbane (2.5 million) into half of Canberra. That’s how crowded it is. And then dropping 6,000 bombs on them over 10 days — that’s the Israeli army’s own figure. A convoy trying to get south a day ago was hit by an Israeli bomb — an estimated 70 people killed and 150 people injured. More than half of those killed children and women. This is without question a humanitarian disaster and, to quote Benjamin Netanyahu, this is only the beginning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is DFAT still advising Australians to move south?

children.content: Al Jazeera is reporting that Israel is not permitting the opening of the Egyptian border crossing. Can the ABC confirm this? Is DFAT still advising Australians to move south?
I’m not sure what DFAT’s latest advice is — it would be on their website — but I do know that the south is likely to be less dangerous than the centre (Gaza City) and the north.
I say “less dangerous” because no-where in Gaza is safe. It’s so small and there’s no-where to get away from the war. In geographic size it’s about half the size of Canberra with 2.3 million people.
To put that into an Australian perspective, imagine putting the population of Brisbane (2.5 million) into half of Canberra. That’s how crowded it is.
And then dropping 6,000 bombs on them over 10 days — that’s the Israeli army’s own figure.
A convoy trying to get south a day ago was hit by an Israeli bomb — an estimated 70 people killed and 150 people injured. More than half of those killed children and women.
This is without question a humanitarian disaster and, to quote Benjamin Netanyahu, this is only the beginning.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hi Jon, I am concerned about civilian hostages.  Have organisations like the Int'l Red Cross had access to hostages? And has the PLO or any Arab states that have called for the release of such hostages? - MikeJ. Hi Mike – I agree that the hostages should be a top priority. The Israeli army says there are 155 hostages in Gaza. They come from several different countries. The US has sent its top hostage expert to Israel. I have no doubt that Israeli, US and several other intelligence services would be working full-time to try to locate the hostages. It seems that the US and Israel have very poor “humint” — human intelligence — in Gaza. Otherwise they would have been tipped off about the Hamas attack. I think that the Arab countries — particularly Qatar and Egypt — will have the best chance of trying to broker a deal to free the hostages. I do not know whether the International Red Cross has had access to them.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What happens next with the civilian hostages held by Hamas?

children.content: Hi Jon, I am concerned about civilian hostages.  Have organisations like the Int'l Red Cross had access to hostages? And has the PLO or any Arab states that have called for the release of such hostages?
Hi Mike – I agree that the hostages should be a top priority. The Israeli army says there are 155 hostages in Gaza. They come from several different countries.
The US has sent its top hostage expert to Israel. I have no doubt that Israeli, US and several other intelligence services would be working full-time to try to locate the hostages.
It seems that the US and Israel have very poor “humint” — human intelligence — in Gaza. Otherwise they would have been tipped off about the Hamas attack.

I think that the Arab countries — particularly Qatar and Egypt — will have the best chance of trying to broker a deal to free the hostages. I do not know whether the International Red Cross has had access to them.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The first flight to evacuate Australians from Israel has just left Tel Aviv. Foreign Minister Penny Wong says another flight is planned for the afternoon. It is currently midday in Israel. She added these two flights may be "our last flights for the foreseeable future". "Australians wanting to leave should strongly consider this option and not wait for a different option," she said on social media.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: First flight leaves Tel Aviv as Australians urged to not wait for 'a different option'

children.content: The first flight to evacuate Australians from Israel has just left Tel Aviv.
Foreign Minister Penny Wong says another flight is planned for the afternoon. It is currently midday in Israel.
She added these two flights may be "our last flights for the foreseeable future".
"Australians wanting to leave should strongly consider this option and not wait for a different option," she said on social media.
